los.title: 3.1: Key Planning Documents
los.preview: Two documents anchor a basic sustainability view.

snippets.title: Body
snippets.body: You need a current Net Worth Statement and a Cash Flow Statement. Together they clarify assets, liabilities, inflows, and outflows.

los.title: 3.2: Positive Cash Flow
los.preview: Cash flow hygiene drives everything else.

snippets.title: Body
snippets.body: Think in systems: predictable inflows, controlled outflows, and buffers for volatility. Small consistent surpluses compound into options.

los.title: 3.3: Compounding Interest
los.preview: Time and consistency are the edge.

snippets.title: Body
snippets.body: Compounding works best with early starts and low frictions. The most important variables are savings rate, time horizon, and cost control.

los.title: 1.1: What's The Perfect Plan?
los.preview: Why a defined, rational planning process matters.

snippets.title: Body
snippets.body: The "perfect" plan aligns with personal values and is feasible. The process should be teachable, repeatable, and transparent.

snippets.title: Body
snippets.body: Independent thinking guided by evidence helps you avoid product bias, marketing noise, and emotional whiplash.

snippets.title: Body
snippets.body: Clarify what a good life looks like to you. Document trade-offs and capture them as policies you can reuse.

los.title: 2.1: Being Real
los.preview: Ground your plan in realistic spending.

snippets.title: Body
snippets.body: Base assumptions on observed data, not wishes. Your plan can only be as reliable as its inputs.

snippets.title: Body
snippets.body: Use a few stable buckets to start. Add detail only where decisions happen.

snippets.title: Body
snippets.body: Model typical inflation and stress for shocks. Adjust periodically instead of chasing headlines.
